title: TeamCity Pipelines Is Now Out of Beta
description: In March 2024, we announced the Beta release of TeamCity Pipelines, a new approach to CI/CD that offers blazing-fast pipelines to optimize your development flow. After six months of fine-tuning, adding features, and gathering feedback, weâ€™re excited to announce that TeamCity Pipelines is officially going GA (General Availability) ðŸŽ‰ This is a major milestone for [â€¦]

excerpt: Powerful YAML, a visual drag-and-drop editor, new VCS providers, and more. Read on to learn about what's new.
text: Powerful CI/CD for DevOps-centric teams New Products News TeamCityTeamCity Pipelines Is Now Out of Beta In March 2024, we announced the Beta release of TeamCity Pipelines, a new approach to CI/CD that offers blazing-fast pipelines to optimize your development flow. After six months of fine-tuning, adding features, and gathering feedback, weâ€™re excited to announce that TeamCity Pipelines is officially going GA (General Availability) ðŸŽ‰ This is a major milestone for us, and we couldnâ€™t have done it without your insights and support throughout the journey. Get your TeamCity Pipelines instance TeamCity Pipelines is packed with exciting new features and ready to handle your CI/CD workflows with ease. Letâ€™s take a closer look at whatâ€™s new. Whatâ€™s new in TeamCity Pipelines Powerful YAML functionality In TeamCity Pipelines, you can build pipelines visually or with YAML. With YAML autocompletion, real-time suggestions help you write pipelines faster and with fewer mistakes â€“ like having a CI/CD co-pilot by your side! Visual drag-and-drop CI/CD pipeline editor Imagine Figma or Miro, but for CI/CD â€“ you can easily define job dependencies, reorder tasks, and map out your pipelines visually with TeamCity Pipelinesâ€™ drag-and-drop editor. Itâ€™s not just about making pipelines look pretty (although they do look fantastic, donâ€™t they?) â€“ itâ€™s about making the entire process more intuitive and efficient. Even if youâ€™re not a YAML expert, youâ€™ll be able to create and edit pipelines with ease. Dependency cache In addition to other pipeline optimization features that speed up builds by up to 40%, weâ€™ve added the dependency cache option. The first time you run your Maven builds, TeamCity Pipelines will cache those dependencies. In future builds, it reuses that cache, meaning faster builds and less load on your infrastructure. Self-hosted agents With self-hosted agents, you can now hook up your own build machines to TeamCity Pipelines. Whether youâ€™re using your own data center or cloud infrastructure, this gives you the flexibility to leverage your existing hardware, maintain security, and scale as needed. Agent terminal If you need to check the environment of an agent that runs your build, the agent terminal feature is what you need. You can open the terminal and connect it directly to the agent during a job to view logs, check installed software, or debug issues â€“ all from the UI. The newest additions We release a new version of the product every three weeks. With the latest update, weâ€™ve added some pretty cool features. Hereâ€™s whatâ€™s new. New VCS providers In addition to GitHub, you can now also create pipelines for your GitLab and Bitbucket projects. Clear indications why a job doesnâ€™t start Sometimes due to a misconfiguration, the job will never star. Perhaps there are no compatible agents that meet the set requirements or theyâ€™re all busy at the moment. Now, TeamCity Pipelines provides a clear explanation of why exactly the build doesnâ€™t start and what you can do about it to get your builds up and running. Self-hosted agents: improvements Along with JetBrains-hosted agents, you can run jobs on self-hosted agents and set requirements like OS, CPU count, architecture, RAM, or custom specs. In this iteration, we added grouping available agents by the OS type. If you set agent requirements that canâ€™t be met, TeamCity Pipelines will also let you know. Gradle cache dependency The Enable dependency cache option lets TeamCity cache dependencies from the first pipeline run and is now available for the Gradle runner too. Learn more about whatâ€™s new in TeamCity Pipelines in our regular Pulse newsletter. Find out whatâ€™s new Give TeamCity Pipelines a try If youâ€™ve been with us throughout the Beta period, first of all â€“ thank you! Your feedback helped shape TeamCity Pipelines into what it is today. For those who are new or havenâ€™t tried it in a while, thereâ€™s never been a better time to jump in and check out the latest possibilities. You can try out TeamCity Pipelines completely for free for 14 days. As always, weâ€™re looking forward to your feedback! You help us make the product better with every release ðŸ«¶ Subscribe to TeamCity Blog updates Discover more
html:
Powerful CI/CD for DevOps-centric teams

New Products News TeamCity

TeamCity Pipelines Is Now Out of Beta

In March 2024, we announced the Beta release of TeamCity Pipelines, a new approach to CI/CD that offers blazing-fast pipelines to optimize your development flow. After six months of fine-tuning, adding features, and gathering feedback, weâ€™re excited to announce that TeamCity Pipelines is officially going GA (General Availability) ðŸŽ‰

This is a major milestone for us, and we couldnâ€™t have done it without your insights and support throughout the journey.

Get your TeamCity Pipelines instance

TeamCity Pipelines is packed with exciting new features and ready to handle your CI/CD workflows with ease. Letâ€™s take a closer look at whatâ€™s new.

Whatâ€™s new in TeamCity Pipelines

Powerful YAML functionality

In TeamCity Pipelines, you can build pipelines visually or with YAML. With YAML autocompletion, real-time suggestions help you write pipelines faster and with fewer mistakes â€“ like having a CI/CD co-pilot by your side!

Visual drag-and-drop CI/CD pipeline editor

Imagine Figma or Miro, but for CI/CD â€“ you can easily define job dependencies, reorder tasks, and map out your pipelines visually with TeamCity Pipelinesâ€™ drag-and-drop editor.

Itâ€™s not just about making pipelines look pretty (although they do look fantastic, donâ€™t they?) â€“ itâ€™s about making the entire process more intuitive and efficient. Even if youâ€™re not a YAML expert, youâ€™ll be able to create and edit pipelines with ease.

Dependency cache

In addition to other pipeline optimization features that speed up builds by up to 40%, weâ€™ve added the dependency cache option. The first time you run your Maven builds, TeamCity Pipelines will cache those dependencies. In future builds, it reuses that cache, meaning faster builds and less load on your infrastructure.

Self-hosted agents

With self-hosted agents, you can now hook up your own build machines to TeamCity Pipelines. Whether youâ€™re using your own data center or cloud infrastructure, this gives you the flexibility to leverage your existing hardware, maintain security, and scale as needed.

Agent terminal

If you need to check the environment of an agent that runs your build, the agent terminal feature is what you need. You can open the terminal and connect it directly to the agent during a job to view logs, check installed software, or debug issues â€“ all from the UI.

The newest additions

We release a new version of the product every three weeks. With the latest update, weâ€™ve added some pretty cool features. Hereâ€™s whatâ€™s new.

New VCS providers

In addition to GitHub, you can now also create pipelines for your GitLab and Bitbucket projects.

Clear indications why a job doesnâ€™t start

Sometimes due to a misconfiguration, the job will never star. Perhaps there are no compatible agents that meet the set requirements or theyâ€™re all busy at the moment.

Now, TeamCity Pipelines provides a clear explanation of why exactly the build doesnâ€™t start and what you can do about it to get your builds up and running.

Self-hosted agents: improvements

Along with JetBrains-hosted agents, you can run jobs on self-hosted agents and set requirements like OS, CPU count, architecture, RAM, or custom specs.

In this iteration, we added grouping available agents by the OS type. If you set agent requirements that canâ€™t be met, TeamCity Pipelines will also let you know.

Gradle cache dependency

The Enable dependency cache option lets TeamCity cache dependencies from the first pipeline run and is now available for the Gradle runner too.

Learn more about whatâ€™s new in TeamCity Pipelines in our regular Pulse newsletter.

Find out whatâ€™s new

Give TeamCity Pipelines a try

If youâ€™ve been with us throughout the Beta period, first of all â€“ thank you! Your feedback helped shape TeamCity Pipelines into what it is today. For those who are new or havenâ€™t tried it in a while, thereâ€™s never been a better time to jump in and check out the latest possibilities.

You can try out TeamCity Pipelines completely for free for 14 days.

As always, weâ€™re looking forward to your feedback! You help us make the product better with every release ðŸ«¶
